try {
 
  var marks = ['first-paint', 'first-contentful-paint', 'userBtnRender', 'appRenderTime'];

  var observer = new window.PerformanceObserver(function(list) {
    var entries = list.getEntries();
    for (var i = 0; i < entries.length; i += 1) {
      var entry = entries[i];
      if (marks.indexOf(entry.name) > -1) {
        var performance = {};
        performance[entry.name] = Math.round(entry.duration || entry.startTime);
        (window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || []).push({
          event: 'performance',
          pageview: {
            performance: performance,
          },
        });
      }
    }
  });
 
  observer.observe({ entryTypes: ['mark', 'measure', 'paint'] });

The United States was absent on a teleconference to raise money toward a vaccine."}],"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html","inLanguage":"en-US","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T09:16:17.960Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T04:00:51.000Z","headline":"Coronavirus World Updates","alternativeHeadline":"$8 Billion Pledged for Global Vaccine Push, but U.S. Opts Out: Live Coverage","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020,"isAccessibleForFree":false,"hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","isAccessibleForFree":false,"cssSelector":".meteredContent"},"isPartOf":{"@type":["CreativeWork","Product"],"name":"The New York Times","productID":"nytimes.com:basic"}}</script><script data-rh="true" type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"LiveBlogPosting","description":"President Trump says the U.S. is pouring billions into its own effort to develop a vaccine. And in Russia, three medical workers who complained about the government’s response have fallen from buildings.","mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html","dateModified":"2020-05-05T09:16:17.960Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T04:00:51.000Z","headline":"Coronavirus World Updates","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Ten players in Germany’s top soccer league were found to have the virus, raising questions about plans for resuming games.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020,"coverageEndTime":"2020-05-05T10:46:17.960Z","coverageStartTime":"2020-05-05T04:00:51.000Z","liveBlogUpdate":[{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":[{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/03/world/coronavirus-map-promo/coronavirus-map-promo-master1050-v370.png","height":700,"width":1050},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/03/world/coronavirus-map-promo/coronavirus-map-promo-square640-v500.png","height":640,"width":640},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/03/world/coronavirus-map-promo/coronavirus-map-promo-threeByTwoMediumAt2X-v513.png","height":1000,"width":1500}],"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-4eff8309","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-4eff8309","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T09:16:17.960Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T09:16:17.960Z","headline":"World leaders join to pledge $8 billion for vaccine, but the U.S. sits out.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"A fund-raising conference on Monday organized by the European Union brought pledges from countries around the world — including Japan, Canada, Australia and Norway — to fund laboratories that have promising leads in developing and producing a vaccine.Prime ministers, a king, a prince and Madonna all chipped in to an $8 billion pot to fund a coronavirus vaccine, but President Trump skipped the chance to contribute. Officials in his administration noted that the United States is pouring billions of dollars into its own research efforts.For more than three hours, one by one, global leaders said a few words over video link and offered their nations’ contribution, small or large, whatever they could muster. For Romania, it was $200,000. For Canada, $850 million. The biggest contributors were the European Union and Norway, with each pledging one billion euros, or $1.1 billion.The details of how the money raised will be distributed remain to be sorted out. The European Commission, the executive branch of the European Union that spearheaded the initiative, said the money would be spent over the next two years to support promising initiatives around the globe. The ultimate goal is to deliver universal and affordable access to medication to fight Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.The multilateral effort stood in sharp contrast to the solo road the United States is on as scientists everywhere scramble to develop a vaccine to stop the virus that has ravaged most parts of the globe, leaving 250,000 dead so far.In Washington on Monday, senior Trump administration officials sought to talk up American contributions to coronavirus vaccine efforts worldwide, but did not explain the United States’ absence at the European-organized conference.The U.S. government has spent money on vaccine research and development, including $2.6 billion through the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority, an arm of the Health and Human Services Department. Jim Richardson, the State Department’s director of foreign assistance, said American companies had also provided $7 billion so far toward a coronavirus vaccine and treatment.And the United States was not the world’s only major power to be absent from the teleconference. Russia, too, did not participate.China, where the virus originated, was represented by its ambassador to the European Union and made no financial pledge.Leaders in China are desperate to protect their people and deflect growing international criticism of how it has handled the coronavirus , wants to come out on top in the race to find a coronavirus vaccine — and by some measures it is doing so.The country has slashed red tape and offered resources to drug companies in a bid to empower the country’s vaccine industry. Four Chinese companies have begun testing their vaccine candidates on humans, more than the United States and Britain combined.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-in-briefing-baseball/merlin_172156557_c59116ec-6cd3-456c-b556-048ed441bae4-superJumbo.jpg","height":1366,"width":2048,"caption":"Dummies and cardboard Cut-outs replaced a live audience during a game between the Rakuten Monkeys and CTBC Brothers at Taoyuan International Baseball Stadium in Taiwan on Saturday."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-18e30e4a","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-18e30e4a","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T08:31:14.108Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T08:31:14.108Z","headline":"With most sports leagues on pause, baseball in Taiwan and South Korea becomes a global hit.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"With sports events canceled across much of the world because of the coronavirus pandemic, Taiwan and South Korea, which have both been world leaders in controlling the outbreak, are pushing forward with the rarest of spectacles: a professional baseball season.South Korea’s season starts Tuesday , while Taiwan got underway last month. To adapt the game to the coronavirus age, live spectators are banned. The relative quiet makes the games now feel more like practice rather than the typically raucous regular season competitions.In Taiwan, the stands are filled with fake spectators instead of real ones, locker rooms stocked with bottles of sanitizer, and players and coaches urged to keep a distance.Chewing sunflower seeds is frowned upon — what would one do with the shells? Players are encouraged to bump elbows rather than give each other high-fives.Players and coaches say they feel fortunate to be able to host games at all when many cities in the world remain under lockdown.“We know many people are still keeping their eyes on us, even though there are no fans, ” said Chiu Chang-Jung, the manager of the CTBC Brothers team, which on Saturday took on the Rakuten Monkeys at the stadium in Taoyuan, about 30 miles west of Taiwan’s capital, Taipei. “Playing these games is a very lucky and blessed thing.”","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/04/world/04virus-int-briefing-boris/merlin_172161465_b3cb2350-1876-4aba-8fad-64cfeb0ebf9e-superJumbo.jpg","height":1036,"width":1555,"caption":"Prime Minister Boris Johnson arriving at Downing Street on Monday."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-3dc23d2e","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-3dc23d2e","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T07:46:10.257Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T07:46:10.257Z","headline":"Under fire from the media, Boris Johnson’s government fires back.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"For a while, as the pandemic worsened, Queen Elizabeth II appealed for solidarity, and a seriously ill Prime Minister Boris Johnson was hospitalized , relations between Britain’s government and its news media got a bit less testy.That’s over.The culture minister recently accused the BBC of bias in reporting on the shortage of protective gear in hospitals. The health secretary heatedly claimed that The Times of London had misstated policy on shielding older people.And 10 Downing Street has posted lengthy rebuttals, by unnamed officials, of newspaper articles that detailed its missteps in dealing with the outbreak.Mr. Johnson has opened his daily briefings to questions and comments from members of the public as well as the press corps, making the famously sharp-tongued British reporters seem meaner by comparison.“It positions the government and the public against the media, at the very moment that the media is presenting itself as the representative of the people in holding the government to account,” said Meera Selva, the director of the Reuters Journalism Fellowship Program at Oxford University.The government was on the defensive in March and into April, amid revelations of testing foul-ups , shortages of protective gear, a fast-rising death toll and the inadequacy of its relaxed initial approach to social distancing, which forced a sharp policy turn . Then came Mr. Johnson’s personal ordeal and week-long hospital stay, winning some sympathy.The criticism has not abated, but now that Mr. Johnson and his allies have ramped up testing and declared that the worst is over, they have gone back on the offensive with the media, trying to put any talk of failure behind them. It is a return to a pugnacious populism that has served them well in the past.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/04/science/05virus-int-briefing-genetherapy/merlin_172185261_12649b52-1ede-40c1-800e-dd49a24c8a41-superJumbo.jpg","height":1412,"width":2048,"caption":"A rendering of the outer shell of an adeno-associated virus with the exterior partially removed. The shell is used as a Trojan horse to deliver a genetic component of the coronavirus to raise an immune response."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-122da669","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-122da669","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T07:01:06.405Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T07:01:06.405Z","headline":"Latest in science: Researchers are adapting gene therapy to develop a vaccine.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Researchers at two Harvard-affiliated hospitals are adapting a proven form of gene therapy to develop a coronavirus vaccine, which they expect to test in people later this year, they announced on Monday.Their work employs a method already used in gene therapy for two inherited diseases, including a form of blindness: It uses a harmless virus as a vector, or carrier, to bring DNA into the patient’s cells. In this case, the DNA should instruct the cells to make a coronavirus protein that would stimulate the immune system to fight off future infections.So far, the team has studied its vaccine candidates only in mice. Tests for safety and potency in monkeys should begin within a month or so at another academic center, the researchers said. But two of seven promising versions are already being manufactured for studies in humans.At this early stage, Dr. Luk H. Vandenberghe, director of the Grousbeck Gene Therapy Center at Massachusetts Eye and Ear, estimates the manufacturing cost per dose of vaccine to be from $2.50 to $250.“We are presenting a different angle from everybody else,” Dr. Vandenberghe, director said. Several other vaccine projects involve viral vectors, but no others use adeno-associated viruses.The approach has several advantages, he added.One is that the type of vector, an adeno-associated virus, or AAV, is a harmless virus that is already used in two approved forms of gene therapy and has been tested in many patients and found to be safe. Another plus is that the technique requires very small amounts of the vector and DNA to produce immunity, so the yield of doses would be high. In addition, many drug and biotech companies, large and small, already produce adeno-associated virus and could easily switch to producing the form needed for the vaccine.The research is one of at least 90 vaccine projects speeding ahead around the world in desperate efforts that hold the best and probably only hope of stopping or at least slowing the pandemic.One potential problem that every vaccine project will be on the lookout for is disease enhancement: the possibility that a vaccine, instead of preventing infection, could actually make the disease worse.The two scientists said the many research groups forging ahead with vaccine projects were racing not against one another, but against the coronavirus.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/10/nyregion/05virus-int-briefing-holocaust/10nyvirus-Holocaust-survivors-01-superJumbo-v2.jpg","height":2000,"width":1463,"caption":"Fay Becher and her husband, Rabbi Szaul Becher. Ms. Becher, who survived Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, contracted the coronavirus and died on April 9."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-264fe9ac","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-264fe9ac","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T06:16:02.554Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T06:16:02.554Z","headline":"They survived the Holocaust, but now they’re confronting the virus.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"The generation that endured Nazi death camps is especially vulnerable to the pandemic.The New York area is home to just under 40,000 Holocaust survivors, down from nearly twice that many in 2011, according to Selfhelp Community Services , which serves Nazi victims. Now those survivors, mostly in their 80s and 90s, face a new menace that targets people like them.“This pandemic is the greatest threat to this generation since the Second World War,” said Stephen D. Smith, executive director of the USC Shoah Foundation, which interviews survivors of genocide.In New York State, the coronavirus has killed more than twice as many people age 80 and up as it has people under 60.One got out of Nazi Germany on a Kindertransport train to Sweden, never again seeing his parents, who were exterminated in the death camps. One survived two notorious concentration camps, Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, and was discovered by British troops on a pile of bodies, half-dead with typhus. One endured freezing temperatures and near starvation in a slave-labor camp in Siberia.Last month, all three died by the same tiny microorganism, isolated once more from their family members.And for survivors who have eluded the virus, memories of that dark time, never far out of mind, find new salience in the present plague.For Diana Kurz, 83, who escaped Vienna with her mother when she was 4 years old, said the coronavirus reminded her of those years in Vienna, when any random encounter might be deadly.“I guess I picked that up as a child,” she said, “that feeling of dread all the time. That’s what it is like now. You never know if other people on the street are going to give you the virus, or were going to turn you in to the Gestapo because you were a Jew.”","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/04/world/04virus-int-briefing-russia/merlin_171748242_c9186af4-d00a-4012-b950-efd76152c959-superJumbo.jpg","height":1270,"width":2048,"caption":"Ambulances outside of a newly built hospital for coronavirus patients in Moscow in late April. Three doctors have reportedly fallen from windows across Russia. Two have died and the third is in critical condition."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-1c10b720","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-1c10b720","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T05:30:58.702Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T05:30:58.702Z","headline":"Three Russian medics have plunged from windows after complaining about officials’ handling of the pandemic.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Three medical workers in Russia who had been in disputes with the health authorities over handling the coronavirus have plunged from upper-story windows, local news outlets have reported.Some reports suggested that the falls, which killed two doctors and left a third in critical condition, were suicides or accidents.They came amid a police crackdown on doctors who have publicly criticized the government’s response. Russian dissidents have long attributed mysterious falls from balconies and other apparent accidents to state violence.Aleksandr Shulepov, a medic for an ambulance service in the Voronezh region, south of Moscow, fell on Saturday from a window of a hospital where he was being treated for Covid-19. He was in critical conduction with a fractured skull.He and a colleague had complained in online videos about a lack of personal protective equipment. He also said he was required to continue working after he tested positive for the virus, according to Vesti Voronezh, a local newspaper.In response to the videos, the police warned Mr. Shulepov’s colleague of possible criminal charges for spreading false information, the paper reported. Mr. Shulepov posted a video recanting his allegations .In the Siberian region of Krasnoyarsk, Elena Nepomnyashchaya, the chief doctor at a hospital, fell from a window on April 26 and died six days later. She had objected to the regional authorities’ plan to treat Covid-19 patients there, according to TBK, a local news outlet, and had complained about insufficient protective equipment.Natalya Lebedeva, the head of the ambulance service at Star City, the Russian cosmonaut training center, died on April 24 after a plunge from a window at a hospital where she was being treated for Covid-19.The authorities reported that it was an accident. The newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets wrote that Ms. Lebedeva had committed suicide after managers accused her of allowing the spread of the virus within the space program.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/04/sports/04virus-int-briefing-soccer/04virus-germansoccer-1-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"Ten players in the Bundesliga, including three from F.C. Cologne, the team practicing above, recently tested positive for the coronavirus."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-77471a29","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-77471a29","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T04:45:54.851Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T04:45:54.851Z","headline":"10 German soccer players test positive for the virus as their league weighs restarting games.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"As one of the first major sports leagues to detail its plans to return to action, Germany’s top soccer league has become the bellwether for restarting sports events postponed by the coronavirus epidemic.That decision became more complicated on Monday when 10 players were found to have the virus after blanket testing of 1,724 individuals from the 36 teams in the top two divisions of the league, the Bundesliga. The majority are believed to be asymptomatic.It was not clear if the results would derail plans to restart the league, a decision that could come on Wednesday. But the test results were seen as a harbinger for the heavy considerations all sports organizations would face as they make reopening plans, many of them contingent on widespread testing.The National Rugby League in Australia — which is aiming to return on May 28 — ran into similar complications. Four players from the South Sydney Rabbitohs were told to stay home from training on Monday because of flulike symptoms. And the coach of the Sydney Roosters, Trent Robinson, also has symptoms and will be tested.If the Bundesliga cannot resume its season, even without spectators — a decision with far-reaching financial implications — it would not bode well for the rest of the soccer world. Germany has been lauded for its relative success containing the outbreak, and has one of the lowest death rates among major countries at less than 10 per 100,000 people.England’s Premier League is expected to decide on Friday whether there is a way forward to reopen amid disharmony among its 20 teams. In Spain and Italy, there are also cautious moves toward playing again. (Spanish players returned to training on Monday but were limited to working out alone.)Elsewhere, that option has been ruled out, most notably in France, where last week the prime minister declared the season over. The seasons in the Netherlands and in Belgium have also been officially called off.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/04/world/04virus-int-briefing-bubble/merlin_169688580_5238b041-d231-49f0-b2dd-9762c7bffc42-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"Prime Ministers Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand and Scott Morrison of Australia in Sydney in February."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-64e91a72","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-64e91a72","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-05-05T04:00:51.000Z","datePublished":"2020-05-05T04:00:51.000Z","headline":"New Zealand and Australia work toward creating a ‘travel bubble.’","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Australia and New Zealand are moving closer toward creating a “travel bubble” that would allow people to fly between the two countries without quarantines — a resumption of traffic that would be a boost for both countries’ economies.Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand, who joined Australia’s cabinet meeting on Tuesday to discuss the steps required, said on Monday that the move would depend on continued progress in testing and tracing of coronavirus infections in both countries. That could take weeks or months.But she emphasized that the prospect of revived travel reflected the shared success of Australia and New Zealand, which have crushed the peaks of their initial outbreaks faster than expected .“Both our countries’ strong record of fighting the virus has placed us in the enviable position of being able to plan the next stage in our economic rebuild,” she said.Ms. Ardern and Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia told reporters on Tuesday that the ‘bubble’ is an important part of the road back to normalcy for both nations.Such a travel arrangement could potentially be extended into the Pacific — Fiji has only a handful of reported cases and zero deaths. And plans are also being laid for limited travel between other countries that have controlled the spread of infection.China and South Korea began easing quarantine requirements for some business travelers on Friday. A day later, trade ministers from Australia, Canada, South Korea, New Zealand and Singapore agreed to a collective effort to resume the flow of not just goods and services, but also people traveling “for purposes such as maintaining global supply chains, including essential business travel,” according to a joint statement.Public health experts say that any resumption of travel comes with risks, but they also note that conditions vary by country. Travelers from the United States, the main source of coronavirus infections in Australia, may have to wait far longer to book flights around the world without being subject to 14-day quarantines.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020}]}</script><script data-rh="true" type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"The New York Times","logo":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/misc/NYT_logo_rss_250x40.png","height":40,"width":250},"url":"https://www.nytimes.com/","@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher","diversityPolicy":"https://www.nytco.com/diversity-and-inclusion-at-the-new-york-times/","ethicsPolicy":"https://www.nytco.com/who-we-are/culture/standards-and-ethics/","masthead":"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/admin/the-new-york-times-masthead.html","foundingDate":"1851-09-18","sameAs":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times"}</script><script data-rh="true" >

      var match = document.cookie.match(new RegExp(name + '=([^;]+)'));
      if (match) return match[1];
    }

    background-color: #D0021B;
    color: white;
    border-radius: 3px;
    padding: 4px 6px 2px 6px;
    margin-right: 2px;
    display: inline-block;
    letter-spacing: 0.03rem;
    font-weight: 700;
  }

  .nytslm_li_upcoming_loud {
    border: 1px solid #d0021b;
    color: #d0021b;
    border-radius: 3px;
    padding: 4px 6px 2px 6px;
    margin-right: 2px;
    display: inline-block;
    letter-spacing: 0.03rem;
    font-weight: 700;
  }

  .nytslm_li_upcoming_loud:before {
    content: 'Upcoming'
  }

  .nytslm_li_loud a:hover,
  .nytslm_li_loud a:active,
  .nytslm_li_loud a:focus {
    border-bottom: 2px solid;
    padding-bottom: 2px;
  }

  #masthead-bar-one {
    display: none;
  }

  /* No hover state on in app */
  .Hybrid .nytslm_li a:hover,
  .Hybrid .nytslm_li_loud a:hover {
    border-bottom: none;
    padding-bottom: 0;
  }

  h2[id^=link-] {
    scroll-margin-top: 24px;
  }
</style>

<nav class="nytslm_outerContainer" id="nytslm"
  data-tracking-params='{"label":"menu","data":[{"index":0,"type":"capsule_menu_element","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/us/coronavirus-updates.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=TOP_BANNER&context=storyline_menu","label":"Latest Updates"},{"index":1,"type":"capsule_menu_element","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/coronavirus-maps.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=TOP_BANNER&context=storyline_menu","label":"Maps and Tracker"},{"index":2,"type":"capsule_menu_element","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/coronavirus-tips-advice.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=TOP_BANNER&context=storyline_menu","label":"Tips and Advice"},{"index":3,"type":"capsule_menu_element","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/at-home?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=TOP_BANNER&context=storyline_menu","label":"Life at Home"},{"index":4,"type":"capsule_menu_element","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/coronavirus-briefing?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=TOP_BANNER&context=storyline_menu","label":"Newsletter"}]}'>

          </a>
        </div>

        </a>

<script>
  var pathname
  if (window.asset && window.asset.url) {
    // hybrid
    pathname = window.asset.url;
  } else {
    // vi
    pathname = window.location.pathname;
  }

  // remove section label from menu if on corona virus section front
  if (document.querySelector('#masthead-section-label') && window.location.pathname.endsWith("news-event/coronavirus")) {
    var css = '#masthead-section-label { display: none; } ';
    var parent = document.querySelector("#nytslm");
    style = document.createElement('style');
    parent.appendChild(style);

    style.type = 'text/css';
    if (style.styleSheet) {
      // This is required for IE8 and below.
      style.styleSheet.cssText = css;
    } else {
      style.appendChild(document.createTextNode(css));
    }
  }

  var tags = document.getElementsByClassName('nytslm_li_link');

  for (var index = 0; index < tags.length; index++) {
    var el = tags[index];
    if (pathname.length && el && el.href && el.href.includes(pathname)) {
      el.classList.add("nytsMenu_li_current");
      break;
    }
  }

  function removeLiveBug() {
    var found = false;
    var spans = document.querySelectorAll('span');
    for (var index = 0; index < spans.length; index++) {
      if (spans[index].textContent === 'LIVE UPDATES') {
        found = true;
        break;
      }
    }

    if (found) {
      var live = document.querySelector('#live');
      if (live) live.remove();
    }
  }

  removeLiveBug();
  document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', removeLiveBug);

</script><!-- Pipeline: 2020-01-23-styln-menu-wuhan-coronavirus | May 5, 2020, 05:21AM | bd35b6ea4b54d022e7fb482e9408f3242278de07 -->
</div></section><div></div></div><div id="top-wrapper" class="css-1sy8kpn"><div id="top-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-top" style="position:absolute;width:1px;height:1px;margin:-1px;padding:0;border:0;clip:rect(0 0 0 0);overflow:hidden">Continue reading the main story</a><div class="ad top-wrapper" style="text-align:center;height:100%;display:block;min-height:250px"><div id="top" class="place-ad" data-position="top" data-size-key="top"></div></div><div id="after-top"></div></div><header class="css-13s9jzp edomiq21"><div class="css-14oxmzc edomiq20"><div class="css-40v4b6"><span class="css-sgss5">LIVE UPDATES</span></div><button aria-live="polite" type="button" aria-label="toggle date display" class="css-1k9ek97"><time class="css-101kej7" dateTime="2020-05-05T09:16:17.960Z"><span class="">Updated </span><div class="css-ki347z"><span class="css-1656jku">May 5, 2020, 5:16 a.m. ET</span><span class="css-xwx5dt"></span></div></time><span class="css-1dv1kvn" aria-live="polite">May 5, 2020, 5:16 a.m. ET</span></button></div><div class="css-1vkm6nb ehdk2mb0"><h1 id="link-39e95cf0" class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" itemProp="headline" data-test-id="headline">$8 Billion Pledged for Global Vaccine Push, but U.S. Opts Out: Live Coverage</h1></div><p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">President Trump says the U.S. is pouring billions into its own effort to develop a vaccine. And in Russia, three medical workers who complained about the government’s response have fallen from buildings.</p><div class="css-192lewg e1oheyly0"><p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">Right Now</p><p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Ten players in Germany’s top soccer league were found to have the virus, raising questions about plans for resuming games.</p></div></header><section name="articleBody" itemProp="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div id="NYT_ABOVE_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION" class=""></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cn.nytimes.com/morning-brief/20200505/coronavirus-briefing/" title="">新冠病毒疫情最新消息</a></p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-19qgada"><h3 class="css-k42qd2 e1gnsphs0">Here’s what you need to know:</h3><ul class="css-1gfen40 ez3869y0"><li class="css-60pazy eoqvrfo0"><a href="#link-4eff8309">World leaders join to pledge $8 billion for vaccine, but the U.S. sits out.</a></li><li class="css-60pazy eoqvrfo0"><a href="#link-18e30e4a">With most sports leagues on pause, baseball in Taiwan and South Korea becomes a global hit.</a></li><li class="css-60pazy eoqvrfo0"><a href="#link-3dc23d2e">Under fire from the media, Boris Johnson’s government fires back.</a></li><li class="css-60pazy eoqvrfo0"><a href="#link-122da669">Latest in science: Researchers are adapting gene therapy to develop a vaccine.</a></li><li class="css-60pazy eoqvrfo0"><a href="#link-264fe9ac">They survived the Holocaust, but now they’re confronting the virus.</a></li><li class="css-60pazy eoqvrfo0"><a href="#link-1c10b720">Three Russian medics have plunged from windows after complaining about officials’ handling of the pandemic.</a></li><li class="css-60pazy eoqvrfo0"><a href="#link-77471a29">10 German soccer players test positive for the virus as their league weighs restarting games.</a></li></ul></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group" itemProp="associatedMedia" itemscope="" itemID="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/merlin_172153926_44819624-3f70-4165-91e4-e6484c113981-articleLarge.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/05virus-int-briefing-trump-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/05virus-int-briefing-trump-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/05virus-int-briefing-trump-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"/><img alt="President Trump participating in a Fox News town hall at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C., on Sunday. The United States was absent on a teleconference to raise money toward a vaccine." class="css-1m50asq" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/merlin_172153926_44819624-3f70-4165-91e4-e6484c113981-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/merlin_172153926_44819624-3f70-4165-91e4-e6484c113981-articleLarge.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/merlin_172153926_44819624-3f70-4165-91e4-e6484c113981-jumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/merlin_172153926_44819624-3f70-4165-91e4-e6484c113981-superJumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" decoding="async" itemProp="url" itemID="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/05/world/05virus-int-briefing-trump/merlin_172153926_44819624-3f70-4165-91e4-e6484c113981-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale"/></picture></div><figcaption itemProp="caption description" class="css-18crmh6 e1xdpqjp0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">President Trump participating in a Fox News town hall at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C., on Sunday. The United States was absent on a teleconference to raise money toward a vaccine.</span><span itemProp="copyrightHolder" class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-4eff8309"></div>World leaders join to pledge $8 billion for vaccine, but the U.S. sits out.</h2><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A fund-raising conference on Monday organized by the European Union brought pledges from countries around the world — including Japan, Canada, Australia and Norway — to fund laboratories that have promising leads in developing and producing a vaccine.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prime ministers, a king, a prince and Madonna all chipped in to an $8 billion pot to fund a coronavirus vaccine, but President Trump skipped the chance to contribute. Officials in his administration noted that the United States is pouring billions of dollars into its own research efforts.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For more than three hours, one by one, global leaders said a few words over video link and offered their nations’ contribution, small or large, whatever they could muster. For Romania, it was $200,000. For Canada, $850 million. The biggest contributors were the European Union and Norway, with each pledging one billion euros, or $1.1 billion.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The details of how the money raised will be distributed remain to be sorted out. The European Commission, the executive branch of the European Union that spearheaded the initiative, said the money would be spent over the next two years to support promising initiatives around the globe. The ultimate goal is to deliver universal and affordable access to medication to fight Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The multilateral effort stood in sharp contrast to the solo road the United States is on as scientists everywhere scramble to develop a vaccine to stop the virus that has ravaged most parts of the globe, leaving <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/coronavirus-maps.html" title="">250,000 dead</a> so far.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Washington on Monday, senior Trump administration officials sought to talk up American contributions to coronavirus vaccine efforts worldwide, but did not explain the United States’ absence at the European-organized conference.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. government has spent money on vaccine research and development, including $2.6 billion through the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority, an arm of the Health and Human Services Department. Jim Richardson, the State Department’s director of foreign assistance, said American companies had also provided $7 billion so far toward a coronavirus vaccine and treatment.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And the United States was not the world’s only major power to be absent from the teleconference. Russia, too, did not participate.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China, where the virus originated, was represented by its ambassador to the European Union and made no financial pledge.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Leaders in China are desperate to protect their people and deflect <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/03/world/europe/backlash-china-coronavirus.html" title="">growing international criticism of how it has handled the coronavirus</a>, wants to come out on top in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/02/us/politics/vaccines-coronavirus-research.html" title="">the race to find a coronavirus vaccine</a> — and by some measures it is doing so.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The country has slashed red tape and offered resources to drug companies in a bid to empower the country’s vaccine industry. Four Chinese companies have begun testing their vaccine candidates on humans, more than the United States and Britain combined.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1sngw6j"><a class="css-1a9ghz5" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/coronavirus-maps.html"><div class="css-1eoytci"><img alt="" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/03/world/coronavirus-map-promo/coronavirus-map-promo-articleLarge-v370.png"/></div><div class="css-1rha1bf"><h2 class="css-zd32qr">Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Global Outbreak</h2><p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has infected more than 3,567,400 people in at least 177 countries.</p></div></a></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-18e30e4a"></div>With most sports leagues on pause, baseball in Taiwan and South Korea becomes a global hit.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With sports events canceled across much of the world because of the coronavirus pandemic, Taiwan and South Korea, which have both been world leaders in controlling the outbreak, are pushing forward with the rarest of spectacles: a professional baseball season.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/sports/baseball/coronavirus-baseball-korea-opening.html" title="">South Korea’s season starts Tuesday</a>, while Taiwan got underway last month. To adapt the game to the coronavirus age, live spectators are banned. The relative quiet makes the games now feel more like practice rather than the typically raucous regular season competitions.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div id="NYT_MID_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION" class="css-9tf9ac"></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Taiwan, the stands are filled with fake spectators instead of real ones, locker rooms stocked with bottles of sanitizer, and players and coaches urged to keep a distance.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chewing sunflower seeds is frowned upon — what would one do with the shells? Players are encouraged to bump elbows rather than give each other high-fives.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Players and coaches say they feel fortunate to be able to host games at all when many cities in the world remain under lockdown.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We know many people are still keeping their eyes on us, even though there are no fans,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">” </strong>said Chiu Chang-Jung, the manager of the CTBC Brothers team, which on Saturday took on the Rakuten Monkeys at the stadium in Taoyuan, about 30 miles west of Taiwan’s capital, Taipei. “Playing these games is a very lucky and blessed thing.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-3dc23d2e"></div>Under fire from the media, Boris Johnson’s government fires back.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For a while, as the pandemic worsened, Queen Elizabeth II appealed for solidarity, and a seriously ill <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/05/world/europe/coronavirus-queen-elizabeth-speech.html" title="">Prime Minister Boris Johnson was hospitalized</a>, relations between Britain’s government and its news media got a bit less testy.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That’s over.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The culture minister recently accused the BBC of bias in reporting on the shortage of protective gear in hospitals. The health secretary heatedly claimed that The Times of London had misstated policy on shielding older people.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And 10 Downing Street has posted lengthy rebuttals, by unnamed officials, of newspaper articles that detailed its missteps in dealing with the outbreak.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Johnson has opened his daily briefings to questions and comments from members of the public as well as the press corps, making the famously sharp-tongued British reporters seem meaner by comparison.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It positions the government and the public against the media, at the very moment that the media is presenting itself as the representative of the people in holding the government to account,” said Meera Selva, the director of the Reuters Journalism Fellowship Program at Oxford University.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government was on the defensive in March and into April, amid revelations of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/02/world/europe/uk-coronavirus-testing.html" title="">testing foul-ups</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/19/health/coronavirus-masks-shortage.html" title="">shortages</a> of protective gear, a fast-rising death toll and the inadequacy of its relaxed initial approach to social distancing, which <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/24/world/europe/britain-coronavirus-lockdown.html" title="">forced a sharp policy turn</a>. Then came Mr. Johnson’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/27/world/europe/coronavirus-britain-boris-johnson.html" title="">personal ordeal and week-long hospital stay,</a> winning some sympathy.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The criticism has not abated, but now that Mr. Johnson and his allies have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/01/world/europe/coronavirus-britain-tests-deaths.html" title="">ramped up testing </a>and declared that the worst is over, they have gone back on the offensive with the media, trying to put any talk of failure behind them. It is a return to a pugnacious populism that has served them well in the past.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-122da669"></div>Latest in science: Researchers are adapting gene therapy to develop a vaccine.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Researchers at two Harvard-affiliated hospitals are adapting a proven form of gene therapy to develop a coronavirus vaccine, which they expect to test in people later this year, they announced on Monday.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their work employs a method already used in gene therapy for two inherited diseases, including a form of blindness: It uses a harmless virus as a vector, or carrier, to bring DNA into the patient’s cells. In this case, the DNA should instruct the cells to make a coronavirus protein that would stimulate the immune system to fight off future infections.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the team has studied its vaccine candidates only in mice. Tests for safety and potency in monkeys should begin within a month or so at another academic center, the researchers said. But two of seven promising versions are already being manufactured for studies in humans.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At this early stage, Dr. Luk H. Vandenberghe, director of the Grousbeck Gene Therapy Center at Massachusetts Eye and Ear, estimates the manufacturing cost per dose of vaccine to be from $2.50 to $250.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We are presenting a different angle from everybody else,” Dr. Vandenberghe, director said. Several other vaccine projects involve viral vectors, but no others use adeno-associated viruses.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The approach has several advantages, he added.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One is that the type of vector, an adeno-associated virus, or AAV, is a harmless virus that is already used in two approved forms of gene therapy and has been tested in many patients and found to be safe. Another plus is that the technique requires very small amounts of the vector and DNA to produce immunity, so the yield of doses would be high. In addition, many drug and biotech companies, large and small, already produce adeno-associated virus and could easily switch to producing the form needed for the vaccine.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The research is one of at least<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/02/us/politics/vaccines-coronavirus-research.html" title=""> 90 vaccine projects speeding ahead</a> around the world in desperate efforts that hold the best and probably only hope of stopping or at least slowing the pandemic.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One potential problem that every vaccine project will be on the lookout for is disease enhancement: the possibility that a vaccine, instead of preventing infection, could actually make the disease worse.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The two scientists said the many research groups forging ahead with vaccine projects were racing not against one another, but against the coronavirus.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-264fe9ac"></div>They survived the Holocaust, but now they’re confronting the virus.</h2><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1m53jiu e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group" itemProp="associatedMedia" itemscope="" itemID="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/10/nyregion/05virus-int-briefing-holocaust/10nyvirus-Holocaust-survivors-01-articleLarge-v2.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><div class="css-zgakxe erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:528.4444444444445px"></div></div></div><figcaption itemProp="caption description" class="css-1e7005o e1xdpqjp0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Fay Becher and her husband, Rabbi Szaul Becher. Ms. Becher, who survived Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, contracted the coronavirus and died on April 9.</span><span itemProp="copyrightHolder" class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>via Ben Becher</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The generation that endured Nazi death camps is especially vulnerable to the pandemic.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The New York area is home to just under 40,000 Holocaust survivors, down from nearly twice that many in 2011, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.selfhelp.net/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Selfhelp Community Services</a>, which serves Nazi victims. Now those survivors, mostly in their 80s and 90s, face a new menace that targets people like them.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This pandemic is the greatest threat to this generation since the Second World War,” said Stephen D. Smith, executive director of the USC Shoah Foundation, which interviews survivors of genocide.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In New York State, the coronavirus has killed more than <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://covid19tracker.health.ny.gov/views/NYS-COVID19-Tracker/NYSDOHCOVID-19Tracker-Fatalities?%3Aembed=yes&amp;%3Atoolbar=no&amp;%3Atabs=n" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">twice as many people age 80</a> and up as it has people under 60.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One got out of Nazi Germany on a Kindertransport train to Sweden, never again seeing his parents, who were exterminated in the death camps. One survived two notorious concentration camps, Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, and was discovered by British troops on a pile of bodies, half-dead with typhus. One endured freezing temperatures and near starvation in a slave-labor camp in Siberia.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last month, all three died by the same tiny microorganism, isolated once more from their family members.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And for survivors who have eluded the virus, memories of that dark time, never far out of mind, find new salience in the present plague.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For Diana Kurz, 83, who escaped Vienna with her mother when she was 4 years old, said the coronavirus reminded her of those years in Vienna, when any random encounter might be deadly.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I guess I picked that up as a child,” she said, “that feeling of dread all the time. That’s what it is like now. You never know if other people on the street are going to give you the virus, or were going to turn you in to the Gestapo because you were a Jew.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-1c10b720"></div>Three Russian medics have plunged from windows after complaining about officials’ handling of the pandemic.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Three medical workers in Russia who had been in disputes with the health authorities over handling the coronavirus have plunged from upper-story windows, local news outlets have reported.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some reports suggested that the falls, which killed two doctors and left a third in critical condition, were suicides or accidents.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They came amid a police crackdown on doctors who have publicly criticized the government’s response. Russian dissidents have long attributed mysterious falls from balconies and other apparent accidents to state violence.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Aleksandr Shulepov, a medic for an ambulance service in the Voronezh region, south of Moscow, fell on Saturday from a window of a hospital where he was being treated for Covid-19. He was in critical conduction with a fractured skull.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He and a colleague had complained <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://vestivrn.ru/news/2020/04/23/u-kolleg-zhalovavshego-na-nekhvatku-sredstv-zashity-medika-pod-voronezhem-podtverdili/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">in online videos</a> about a lack of personal protective equipment. He also said he was required to continue working after he tested positive for the virus, according to Vesti Voronezh, a local newspaper.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In response to the videos, the police warned Mr. Shulepov’s colleague of possible criminal charges for spreading false information, the paper reported. Mr. Shulepov posted a video <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://vestivrn.ru/news/2020/04/25/zarazivshiisya-covid-19-vrach-iz-bolnicy-pod-voronezhem-oproverg-prinuzhdenie-k-rabote/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">recanting his allegations</a>.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the Siberian region of Krasnoyarsk, Elena Nepomnyashchaya, the chief doctor at a hospital, fell from a window on April 26 and died six days later. She had objected to the regional authorities’ plan to treat Covid-19 patients there, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://tvk6.ru/publications/news/49795/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">TBK,</a> a local news outlet, and had complained about insufficient protective equipment.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Natalya Lebedeva, the head of the ambulance service at Star City, the Russian cosmonaut training center, died on April 24 after a plunge from a window at a hospital where she was being treated for Covid-19.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.rbc.ru/society/27/04/2020/5ea6f2739a7947a6152340b5" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">reported</a> that it was an accident. The newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.mk.ru/incident/2020/04/26/vyyasnilos-v-chem-obvinyali-pokonchivshuyu-s-soboy-glavvracha-zvezdnogo-gorodka.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">wrote</a> that Ms. Lebedeva had committed suicide after managers accused her of allowing the spread of the virus within the space program.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-77471a29"></div>10 German soccer players test positive for the virus as their league weighs restarting games.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As one of the first major sports leagues to detail its plans to return to action, Germany’s top soccer league has become the bellwether for restarting sports events postponed by the coronavirus epidemic.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That decision became more complicated on Monday when 10 players were found to have the virus after blanket testing of 1,724 individuals from the 36 teams in the top two divisions of the league, the Bundesliga. The majority are believed to be asymptomatic.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was not clear if the results would derail plans to restart the league, a decision that could come on Wednesday. But the test results were seen as a harbinger for the heavy considerations all sports organizations would face as they make reopening plans, many of them contingent on widespread testing.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The National Rugby League in Australia — which is aiming to return on May 28 — ran into similar complications. Four players from the South Sydney Rabbitohs were told to stay home from training on Monday because of flulike symptoms. And the coach of the Sydney Roosters, Trent Robinson, also has symptoms and will be tested.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If the Bundesliga cannot resume its season, even without spectators — a decision with far-reaching financial implications — it would not bode well for the rest of the soccer world. Germany has been lauded for its relative success containing the outbreak, and has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/coronavirus-maps.html#countries" title="">one of the lowest death rates among major countries</a> at less than 10 per 100,000 people.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">England’s Premier League is expected to decide on Friday whether there is a way forward to reopen amid disharmony among its 20 teams. In Spain and Italy, there are also cautious moves toward playing again. (Spanish players returned to training on Monday but were limited to working out alone.)</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Elsewhere, that option has been ruled out, most notably in France, where last week the prime minister declared the season over. The seasons in the Netherlands and in Belgium have also been officially called off.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1j6xuz eoo0vm40" id=""><div class="css-105iojl" id="link-64e91a72"></div>New Zealand and Australia work toward creating a ‘travel bubble.’</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Australia and New Zealand are moving closer toward creating a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/29/travel/coronavirus-travel-bubble.html" title="">“travel bubble”</a> that would allow people to fly between the two countries without quarantines — a resumption of traffic that would be a boost for both countries’ economies.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand, who joined Australia’s cabinet meeting on Tuesday to discuss the steps required, said on Monday that the move would depend on continued progress in testing and tracing of coronavirus infections in both countries. That could take weeks or months.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But she emphasized that the prospect of revived travel reflected the shared success of Australia and New Zealand, which have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/24/world/australia/new-zealand-coronavirus.html" title="">crushed the peaks of their initial outbreaks faster than expected</a>.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Both our countries’ strong record of fighting the virus has placed us in the enviable position of being able to plan the next stage in our economic rebuild,” she said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Ardern and Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia told reporters on Tuesday that the ‘bubble’ is an important part of the road back to normalcy for both nations.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Such a travel arrangement could potentially be extended into the Pacific — Fiji has only a handful of reported cases and zero deaths. And plans are also being laid for limited travel between other countries that have controlled the spread of infection.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China and South Korea began easing quarantine requirements for some business travelers on Friday. A day later, trade ministers from Australia, Canada, South Korea, New Zealand and Singapore agreed to a collective effort to resume the flow of not just goods and services, but also people traveling “for purposes such as maintaining global supply chains, including essential business travel,” according to a joint statement.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Public health experts say that any resumption of travel comes with risks, but they also note that conditions vary by country. Travelers from the United States, the main source of coronavirus infections in Australia, may have to wait far longer to book flights around the world without being subject to 14-day quarantines.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Mark Landler, Stephen Castle, Andrew Keh, Javier C. Hernández, Damien Cave, Andrew E. Kramer, Denise Grady, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Lara Jakes and John Leland.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div></section><div></div><div></div><div id="NYT_BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION" class=""><section id="styln-faq-coronavirus" class="css-l08pwh interactive-content interactive-size-medium"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body"><!--
