  .g-table-text {
    font-family: "nyt-franklin", arial, helvetica, sans-serif;
  }

  .g-body,
  .g-body_bullet,
  .g-body_link {
    font-family: "nyt-imperial", georgia, "times new roman", times, serif;
  }

  /* Light text */
  .g-asset-leadin.g-caption_heading,
  .g-chart,
  .g-headline,
  .interactive-heading,
  .g-label,
  .g-label_white,
  .g-leadin,
  #interactive-leadin,
  .g-table-text {
    font-weight: 300;
  }

  /* Normal text */
  /* Medium text */
  .g-alert,
  .g-alert.g-body,
  .g-alert .g-body,
  .g-alert_link,
  .g-body,
  .g-body_bullet,
  .g-body_link,
  .g-caption,
  .g-credit,
  .g-dateline,
  .g-refer,
  .g-refer.g-body,
  .g-refer .g-body,
  .g-refer_link,
  .g-subhed {
    font-weight: 500;
  }

  /* Bold text */
  .g-byline,
  .g-caption_bold,
  .g-caption_heading,
  .g-chart-header,
  .g-credit_bullet,
  .g-subhed,
  .g-table-heading {
    font-weight: 700;
  }

  strong {
    font-weight: 700;
  }

  /*
 Type Mixins
*************************/
  /* MODULE : GUIDE */
  /**********************/
  .g-inlineguide-list-circle li {
    position: relative;
    padding-left: 1.75em;
  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {

    .g-inlineguide-list-circle p,
    .g-inlineguide-list-circle div,
    .g-inlineguide-list-circle li {
      padding-left: 0;
    }
  }

  .g-inlineguide-list-circle li:before {
    position: absolute;
    content: "•";
    top: 2px;
    left: 1em;
    font-size: 15px;
    line-height: 24px;
  }

  @media (min-width: 600px) {

    .g-inlineguide-list-circle li:before {
      top: 3px;
      left: -1em;
    }
  }

  .g-inlineguide {
    background-color: #f3f3f3;
    text-align: left;
    margin: 30px auto;
    height: 380px;
    width: calc(100% - 40px);
    border-radius: 10px;
    transition: height 0.5s;
  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {
    .g-inlineguide {
      max-width: 600px;
    }
  }

  #truncate-content {
    transition: height 0.5s;
    height: 300px;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-container {
    margin: 0 20px 0px 20px;
    padding: 20px 0 7px 0;
  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {
    .g-inlineguide-container {
      margin: 0 35px 0px 35px;
    }
  }

  .g-inlineguide-container-wrapper {
    height: 100%;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-bottom {
    display: -ms-flexbox;
    display: flex;
    -ms-flex-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    -ms-flex-line-pack: center;
    align-content: center;
    -ms-flex-pack: center;
    justify-content: center;
    top: 10px;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-content {
    position: relative;
    height: 300px;
    max-width: 520px;
    overflow: hidden;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-logo {
    margin: 0 0 10px 0;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-date {
    font-family: "nyt-franklin", arial, helvetica, sans-serif;
    font-size: 13px;
    font-weight: 500;
    line-height: 25px;
    color: #666666;
    max-width: 600px;
    margin: 5px auto 15px;
  }

  #g-inlineguide-headline {
    font-family: "nyt-franklin", arial, helvetica, sans-serif;
    font-size: 13px;
    font-weight: 700;
    line-height: 20px;
    max-width: 600px;

  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {
    #g-inlineguide-headline {
      font-size: 16px;
    }
  }

  /* LINKS */
  #g-inlineguide-id a {
    text-decoration: none;
  }

  .g-inlineguide a {
    color: #326891;
    text-decoration: none;
    border-bottom: 2px solid #CCD9E3;
  }

  .g-inlineguide a:visited {
    color: #333;
    text-decoration: none;
    border-bottom: 2px solid #ddd;
  }

  .g-inlineguide a:hover {
    border-bottom: none;
  }

  .g-inlineguide #g-inlineguide-headline a {
    color: #333;
    text-decoration: none;
    border-bottom: 0px solid #ddd;
  }
  .g-inlineguide #g-inlineguide-headline a:hover {
    border-bottom: 2px solid #ddd;
  }

  /* LIST */
  .g-inlineguide-list-header {
    font-family: nyt-cheltenham, georgia, "times new roman", times, serif;
    font-weight: 500;
    font-size: 26px;
    line-height: 30px;
    margin-top: 5px;
    margin-bottom: 5px;
  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {
    .g-inlineguide-list-header {
      font-size: 30px;
      line-height: 36px;
      margin-bottom: 10px;
      margin-top: 10px;
    }
  }

  .g-inlineguide-item-list {
    font-size: 15px;
    line-height: 20px;
    font-family: "nyt-franklin", arial, helvetica, sans-serif;
    font-weight: 500;
  }

  #g-inlineguide-item-list li {
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    padding-left: 15px;
    line-height: 20px;
  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {
    #g-inlineguide-item-list li {
      line-height: 22px;
      font-size: 16px;
    }
  }

  #g-inlineguide-item-list li:before {
    color: #333333;
    margin-left: -15px;
    margin-right: 10px;
    top: 0;
    font-size: 16px;
  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {
    #g-inlineguide-item-list li:before {
      left: 1em;
    }
  }

  ul.g-inlineguide-list {
    max-width: 600px;
    margin: auto;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-line-truncated {
    background-image: linear-gradient(180deg, transparent, #f3f3f3);
    background-image: -webkit-linear-gradient(270deg, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0), #f3f3f3);
    height: 50px;
    border-bottom: 0.5px solid #dcddda;
    width: calc(90% - 70px);
    margin-top: -55px;
    position: absolute;
  }

  @media (min-width: 740px) {
    .g-inlineguide-line-truncated {
      max-width: 520px;
      width: 90%;
    }
  }

  /* viewport example
.g-element {
    max-width: 100%;
    @include viewport('small') { // 600px
        max-width: 90%;
    }
    @include viewport('medium') { // 740px
        max-width: 80%;
    }
    @include viewport('large')  { // 1024px
        max-width: 70%;
    }
}
*/
  .g-inlineguide-truncate-button {
    display: -ms-flexbox;
    display: flex;
    -ms-flex-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    -ms-flex-line-pack: center;
    align-content: center;
    -ms-flex-pack: center;
    justify-content: center;
    margin: 10px 0 0 28px;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-truncate-button-text {
    font-family: "nyt-franklin", arial, helvetica, sans-serif;
    margin-top: 9px;
    font-size: 13px;
    font-weight: 650;
    line-height: 28px;
    /* or 215% */
    letter-spacing: 0.03em;
    text-transform: uppercase;
    color: #333333;
    background-color: transparent;
  }

  #g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform {
    margin-top: 8px;
    width: 28px;
    height: 28px;
    margin-left: 3px;
    background-color: #F4F5F2;
    display: -ms-flexbox;
    display: flex;
    -ms-flex-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    -ms-flex-pack: center;
    justify-content: center;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform-show {
    transform: rotate(180deg);
    transition: transform 0.5s ease;
  }

  .g-inlineguide-line {
    border: 0.5px solid #dcddda;
    width: 100%;
    max-width: 600px;
    margin: auto;
    margin-top: 20px;
  }
  .g-headline-group{
    display: flex;
    align-items: baseline;

  }
  .g-inlineguide-headline-carat{
    margin-left: 6px;
  }
</style>



<div id="g-inlineguide-id" class="g-inlineguide">
  <div class="g-inlineguide-container">
    <div class="g-inlineguide-container-wrapper">
      <div id="truncate-content" class="g-inlineguide-content">
        <div class="g-headline-group">
        <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">
          <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/news-event/coronavirus?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">The Coronavirus Outbreak</a>

        </h1>
        
        <div class="g-inlineguide-headline-carat">
          <svg width="7" height="11" viewBox="0 0 7 11" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
            <mask id="mask0" mask-type="alpha" maskUnits="userSpaceOnUse" x="0" y="0" width="7" height="11">
            <path d="M0 9.7075L4.07935 5.5L0 1.2925L1.25587 0L6.6 5.5L1.25587 11L0 9.7075Z" fill="white"/>
            </mask>
            <g mask="url(#mask0)">
            <path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M0 0H7V5.5V11H0V0Z" fill="#333333"/>
            </g>
          </svg>
        </div>
        
      </div>
        <ul class="g-inlineguide-list">
          
          <li>
            <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">Frequently Asked Questions and Advice</h2>
            <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated April 11, 2020</p>

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>What should I do if I feel sick?</strong></h4>
                <p><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/22/well/what-if-i-have-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">If you’ve been exposed to the coronavirus or think you have,</a> and have a fever or symptoms like a cough or difficulty breathing, call a doctor. They should give you advice on whether you should be tested, how to get tested, and how to seek medical treatment without potentially infecting or exposing others.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>When will this end?</strong></h4>
                <p>This is a difficult question, because a lot depends on<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/03/20/us/coronavirus-model-us-outbreak.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq"> how well the virus is contained</a>. A better question might be: “How will we know when to reopen the country?” In <a href="https://www.aei.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/National-Coronavirus-Response-a-Road-Map-to-Recovering-2.pdf">an American Enterprise Institute report</a>, Scott Gottlieb, Caitlin Rivers, Mark B. McClellan, Lauren Silvis and Crystal Watson <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/06/upshot/coronavirus-four-benchmarks-reopening.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">staked out four goal posts for recovery</a>: Hospitals in the state must be able to safely treat all patients requiring hospitalization, without resorting to crisis standards of care; the state needs to be able to at least test everyone who has symptoms; the state is able to conduct monitoring of confirmed cases and contacts; and there must be a sustained reduction in cases for at least 14 days.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>How can I help?</strong></h4>
                <p>The Times Neediest Cases Fund has started a special campaign to help those who have been affected, which accepts <a href="https://charity.gofundme.com/o/en/campaign/neediest-cases-fund-covid-relief">donations here</a>. <a href="https://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=content.view&cpid=7779">Charity Navigator</a>, which evaluates charities using a numbers-based system, has a running list of nonprofits working in communities affected by the outbreak. You can give blood through the <a href="https://www.redcrossblood.org/donate-blood/dlp/coronavirus--covid-19--and-blood-donation.html">American Red Cross</a>, and <a href="https://wck.org/">World Central Kitchen</a> has stepped in to distribute meals in major cities. More than 30,000 coronavirus-related <a href="https://www.gofundme.com/c/act/covid19">GoFundMe fund-raisers</a> have started in the past few weeks. (The sheer number of fund-raisers <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/26/style/gofundme-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">means more of them are likely to fail </a>to meet their goal, though.)</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>Should I wear a mask?</strong></h4>
                <p>The C.D.C. has <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/world/coronavirus-news-updates.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">recommended</a> that all Americans wear cloth masks if they go out in public. This is a shift in federal guidance reflecting<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/31/health/coronavirus-asymptomatic-transmission.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq"> new concerns that the coronavirus is being spread by infected people who have no symptoms</a>. Until now, the C.D.C., like the W.H.O., has advised that ordinary people don’t need to wear masks unless they are sick and coughing. Part of the reason was to preserve medical-grade masks for health care workers who desperately need them at a time when they are in continuously short supply. Masks don’t replace hand washing and social distancing.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>How do I get tested?</strong></h4>
                <p>If you’re sick and you think you’ve been exposed to the new coronavirus, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/22/well/what-if-i-have-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">the C.D.C. recommends that you call your healthcare provider and explain your symptoms and fears. </a>They will decide if you need to be tested. Keep in mind that there’s a chance — because of a lack of testing kits or because you’re asymptomatic, for instance — you won’t be able to get tested.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>How does coronavirus spread?</strong></h4>
                <p>It seems to spread <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/03/22/world/coronavirus-spread.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">very easily from person to person,</a> especially in homes, hospitals and other confined spaces. The pathogen can be carried on tiny respiratory droplets that fall as they are coughed or sneezed out. It may also be transmitted when we touch a contaminated surface and then touch our face.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>Is there a vaccine yet?</strong></h4>
                <p>No. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/19/us/politics/coronavirus-vaccine-competition.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">Clinical trials are underway</a> in the United States, China and Europe. But American officials and pharmaceutical executives have said that a vaccine remains at least 12 to 18 months away.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>What makes this outbreak so different?</strong></h4>
                <p>Unlike the flu, there is no known treatment or vaccine, and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">little is known about this particular virus so far.</a> It seems to be more lethal than the flu, but the numbers are still uncertain. And it hits the elderly and those with underlying conditions — not just those with respiratory diseases — particularly hard.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>What if somebody in my family gets sick?</strong></h4>
                <p>If the family member doesn’t need hospitalization and can be cared for at home, you should help him or her with basic needs and monitor the symptoms, while also keeping as much distance as possible, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/22/well/what-if-i-have-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">according to guidelines issued by the C.D.C.</a> If there’s space, the sick family member should stay in a separate room and use a separate bathroom. If masks are available, both the sick person and the caregiver should wear them when the caregiver enters the room. Make sure not to share any dishes or other household items and to regularly clean surfaces like counters, doorknobs, toilets and tables. Don’t forget to wash your hands frequently.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>Should I stock up on groceries?</strong></h4>
                <p>Plan two weeks of meals if possible. But people should not hoard food or supplies. Despite the empty shelves, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/15/business/coronavirus-food-shortages.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">the supply chain remains strong.</a> And remember to wipe the handle of the grocery cart with a disinfecting wipe and wash your hands as soon as you get home.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>Can I go to the park?</strong></h4>
                <p>Yes, but make sure you keep six feet of distance between you and people who don’t live in your home. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/19/well/move/coronavirus-covid-exercise-outdoors-infection-fitness.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">Even if you just hang out in a park, rather than go for a jog or a walk, getting some fresh air, and hopefully sunshine, is a good idea.</a></p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>Should I pull my money from the markets?</strong></h4>
                <p><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/26/your-money/stock-market-changes-virus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">That’s not a good idea.</a> Even if you’re retired, having a balanced portfolio of stocks and bonds so that your money keeps up with inflation, or even grows, makes sense. But retirees may want to think about having enough cash set aside for a year’s worth of living expenses and big payments needed over the next five years.</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
            
            <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
              <li>
                <h4><strong>What should I do with my 401(k)?</strong></h4>
                <p>Watching your balance go up and down can be scary. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/07/your-money/target-date-funds-stock-market.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_faq">You may be wondering if you should decrease your contributions — don’t!</a> If your employer matches any part of your contributions, make sure you’re at least saving as much as you can to get that “free money.”</p>
              </li>
            </ul>
            

            
          </li>
          
        </ul>
        <hr class="g-inlineguide-line" />
      </div>
      <div id="g-inlineguide-bottom">
        <div id="g-inlineguide-line-truncated" class="g-inlineguide-line-truncated"></div>
        <div class="g-inlineguide-truncate-button" onclick="expandGuide()">
          <input type="button" id="g-button" value="Read more" class="g-inlineguide-truncate-button-text">
          <div id="g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform">
            <svg width="13" height="13" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 15 10">
              <defs>
                <style>
                  .cls-1 {
                    fill: #111;
                  }
                </style>
              </defs>
              <polygon class="cls-1" points="7.5 9.31 0.29 2.1 1.71 0.69 7.5 6.48 13.29 0.69 14.71 2.1 7.5 9.31" />
            </svg>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>


<script>

  function add(data) {
    try {
      (window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || []).push(data);
    } catch (ex) {
      // do nothing
    }
  }

  function expandGuide() {

    var modal_element = document.getElementById('g-inlineguide-id');
    var regiId = (window.document.cookie.match(/(?:^|;) *NYT-S=([^;]*)/) || [])[1] || (window.document.cookie.match(/(?:^|;) *nyt-a=([^;]*)/) || [])[1];
    var clickType = document.getElementById("g-button").value == 'Read more' ? 'expand' : 'collapse';

    add({
      event: 'moduleInteraction',
      module: {
        region: 'inline',
        name: 'STYLN_coronavirus_guide',
        label: '1_coronavirus_guide',
        context: 'storyline_guide'
      },
      eventData: {
        type: clickType,
      },
      user: {
        regiId: regiId,
      },
    });

    var element = document.getElementById('truncate-content');
    var modal_element = document.getElementById('g-inlineguide-id');

    if (document.getElementById("g-button").value == 'Read more') {
      document.getElementById("g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform").classList.add("g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform-show");
      document.getElementById("g-button").value = 'Collapse';
      document.getElementById("g-inlineguide-line-truncated").style.display = "none";
      element.style.height = element.scrollHeight + "px";
      modal_element.style.height = (element.scrollHeight + 80) + "px";
    } else {
      document.getElementById("g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform").classList.remove("g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform-show");
      document.getElementById("g-button").value = 'Read more';
      document.getElementById("g-inlineguide-line-truncated").style.display = "flex";
      element.style.height = 300 + "px";
      modal_element.style.height = 380 + "px";
    };
  }

</script>

while Taiwan got underway last month. To adapt the game to the coronavirus age, live spectators are banned. In this case, the DNA should instruct the cells to make a coronavirus protein that would stimulate the immune system to fight off future infections.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2E1MDZjOTViLTM0YmYtNTJhNS04NjNhLTI0NjYwMjc2YjFkZg==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.77.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"So far, the team has studied its vaccine candidates only in mice. Another plus is that the technique requires very small amounts of the vector and DNA to produce immunity, so the yield of doses would be high. In addition, many drug and biotech companies, large and small, already produce adeno-associated virus and could easily switch to producing the form needed for the vaccine.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2E1MDZjOTViLTM0YmYtNTJhNS04NjNhLTI0NjYwMjc2YjFkZg==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.86.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The \u003Ch2 class=\"g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type\"\u003EFrequently Asked Questions and Advice\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n            \u003Cp class=\"g-inlineguide-date\"\u003EUpdated April 11, 2020\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat should I do if I feel sick?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F22\u002Fwell\u002Fwhat-if-i-have-coronavirus.html\"\u003EIf you’ve been exposed to the coronavirus or think you have,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and have a fever or symptoms like a cough or difficulty breathing, call a doctor. They should give you advice on whether you should be tested, how to get tested, and how to seek medical treatment without potentially infecting or exposing others.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhen will this end?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EThis is a difficult question, because a lot depends on\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fus\u002Fcoronavirus-model-us-outbreak.html\"\u003E how well the virus is contained\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. A better question might be: “How will we know when to reopen the country?” In \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.aei.org\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNational-Coronavirus-Response-a-Road-Map-to-Recovering-2.pdf\"\u003Ean American Enterprise Institute report\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Scott Gottlieb, Caitlin Rivers, Mark B. McClellan, Lauren Silvis and Crystal Watson \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F04\u002F06\u002Fupshot\u002Fcoronavirus-four-benchmarks-reopening.html\"\u003Estaked out four goal posts for recovery\u003C\u002Fa\u003E: Hospitals in the state must be able to safely treat all patients requiring hospitalization, without resorting to crisis standards of care; the state needs to be able to at least test everyone who has symptoms; the state is able to conduct monitoring of confirmed cases and contacts; and there must be a sustained reduction in cases for at least 14 days.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EHow can I help?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EThe Times Neediest Cases Fund has started a special campaign to help those who have been affected, which accepts \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcharity.gofundme.com\u002Fo\u002Fen\u002Fcampaign\u002Fneediest-cases-fund-covid-relief\"\u003Edonations here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.charitynavigator.org\u002Findex.cfm?bay=content.view&cpid=7779\"\u003ECharity Navigator\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, which evaluates charities using a numbers-based system, has a running list of nonprofits working in communities affected by the outbreak. You can give blood through the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.redcrossblood.org\u002Fdonate-blood\u002Fdlp\u002Fcoronavirus--covid-19--and-blood-donation.html\"\u003EAmerican Red Cross\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwck.org\u002F\"\u003EWorld Central Kitchen\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has stepped in to distribute meals in major cities. More than 30,000 coronavirus-related \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.gofundme.com\u002Fc\u002Fact\u002Fcovid19\"\u003EGoFundMe fund-raisers\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have started in the past few weeks. (The sheer number of fund-raisers \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F26\u002Fstyle\u002Fgofundme-coronavirus.html\"\u003Emeans more of them are likely to fail \u003C\u002Fa\u003Eto meet their goal, though.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EShould I wear a mask?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EThe C.D.C. has \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F04\u002F03\u002Fworld\u002Fcoronavirus-news-updates.html\"\u003Erecommended\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that all Americans wear cloth masks if they go out in public. This is a shift in federal guidance reflecting\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F31\u002Fhealth\u002Fcoronavirus-asymptomatic-transmission.html\"\u003E new concerns that the coronavirus is being spread by infected people who have no symptoms\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Until now, the C.D.C., like the W.H.O., has advised that ordinary people don’t need to wear masks unless they are sick and coughing. Part of the reason was to preserve medical-grade masks for health care workers who desperately need them at a time when they are in continuously short supply. Masks don’t replace hand washing and social distancing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EHow do I get tested?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EIf you’re sick and you think you’ve been exposed to the new coronavirus, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F22\u002Fwell\u002Fwhat-if-i-have-coronavirus.html\"\u003Ethe C.D.C. recommends that you call your healthcare provider and explain your symptoms and fears. \u003C\u002Fa\u003EThey will decide if you need to be tested. Keep in mind that there’s a chance — because of a lack of testing kits or because you’re asymptomatic, for instance — you won’t be able to get tested.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EHow does coronavirus spread?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EIt seems to spread \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F22\u002Fworld\u002Fcoronavirus-spread.html\"\u003Every easily from person to person,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E especially in homes, hospitals and other confined spaces. The pathogen can be carried on tiny respiratory droplets that fall as they are coughed or sneezed out. It may also be transmitted when we touch a contaminated surface and then touch our face.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIs there a vaccine yet?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003ENo. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F19\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcoronavirus-vaccine-competition.html\"\u003EClinical trials are underway\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in the United States, China and Europe. But American officials and pharmaceutical executives have said that a vaccine remains at least 12 to 18 months away.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat makes this outbreak so different?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EUnlike the flu, there is no known treatment or vaccine, and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Farticle\u002Fwhat-is-coronavirus.html\"\u003Elittle is known about this particular virus so far.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E It seems to be more lethal than the flu, but the numbers are still uncertain. And it hits the elderly and those with underlying conditions — not just those with respiratory diseases — particularly hard.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat if somebody in my family gets sick?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EIf the family member doesn’t need hospitalization and can be cared for at home, you should help him or her with basic needs and monitor the symptoms, while also keeping as much distance as possible, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F22\u002Fwell\u002Fwhat-if-i-have-coronavirus.html\"\u003Eaccording to guidelines issued by the C.D.C.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E If there’s space, the sick family member should stay in a separate room and use a separate bathroom. If masks are available, both the sick person and the caregiver should wear them when the caregiver enters the room. Make sure not to share any dishes or other household items and to regularly clean surfaces like counters, doorknobs, toilets and tables. Don’t forget to wash your hands frequently.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EShould I stock up on groceries?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EPlan two weeks of meals if possible. But people should not hoard food or supplies. Despite the empty shelves, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F15\u002Fbusiness\u002Fcoronavirus-food-shortages.html\"\u003Ethe supply chain remains strong.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E And remember to wipe the handle of the grocery cart with a disinfecting wipe and wash your hands as soon as you get home.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECan I go to the park?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EYes, but make sure you keep six feet of distance between you and people who don’t live in your home. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F19\u002Fwell\u002Fmove\u002Fcoronavirus-covid-exercise-outdoors-infection-fitness.html\"\u003EEven if you just hang out in a park, rather than go for a jog or a walk, getting some fresh air, and hopefully sunshine, is a good idea.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EShould I pull my money from the markets?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F02\u002F26\u002Fyour-money\u002Fstock-market-changes-virus.html\"\u003EThat’s not a good idea.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Even if you’re retired, having a balanced portfolio of stocks and bonds so that your money keeps up with inflation, or even grows, makes sense. But retirees may want to think about having enough cash set aside for a year’s worth of living expenses and big payments needed over the next five years.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n            \n            \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n              \u003Cli\u003E\n                \u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat should I do with my 401(k)?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n                \u003Cp\u003EWatching your balance go up and down can be scary. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F07\u002Fyour-money\u002Ftarget-date-funds-stock-market.html\"\u003EYou may be wondering if you should decrease your contributions — don’t!\u003C\u002Fa\u003E If your employer matches any part of your contributions, make sure you’re at least saving as much as you can to get that “free money.”\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n              \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n            \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n            \n\n            \n          \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n          \n        \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n        \u003Chr (window.document.cookie.match(\u002F(?:^|;) *NYT-S=([^;]*)\u002F) || [])[1] || (window.document.cookie.match(\u002F(?:^|;) *nyt-a=([^;]*)\u002F) || [])[1];\n    var clickType = document.getElementById(\"g-button\").value == 'Read more' ? 'expand' : 'collapse';\n\n    add({\n      event: 'moduleInteraction',\n      module: {\n        region: 'inline',\n        name: 'STYLN_coronavirus_guide',\n        label: '1_coronavirus_guide',\n document.getElementById(\"g-inlineguide-line-truncated\").style.display = \"none\";\n      element.style.height = element.scrollHeight + \"px\";\n      modal_element.style.height = (element.scrollHeight + 80) + \"px\";\n    } else {\n      document.getElementById(\"g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform\").classList.remove(\"g-inlineguide-expand-carat-transform-show\");\n     <script>
    (function(){
      if (document.cookie.indexOf('NYT-S') === -1) {
        var iframe = document.createElement('iframe');
        iframe.height = 0;
        iframe.width = 0;
        iframe.style.display = 'none';
        iframe.style.visibility = 'hidden';
        iframe.src = 'https://myaccount.nytimes.com/auth/prefetch-assets';
        document.body.appendChild(iframe);
      }
    })();
    </script>

  w[l] = w[l] || [];
  w[l].push({
    'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(),
    event: 'gtm.js'
  });
})(window, 'dataLayer');

<iframe src="https://www.googletagmanager.com/ns.html?id=GTM-P528B3&gtm_auth=tfAzqo1rYDLgYhmTnSjPqw&gtm_preview=env-130&gtm_cookies_win=x" height="0" width="0" style="display:none;visibility:hidden"></iframe>

    <div id="RavenInstaller">
<script>
if (window.INSTALL_RAVEN) {
  function installRaven() {
    /* eslint-disable */
// Install Raven
window.Raven
  .config('https://7bc8bccf5c254286a99b11c68f6bf4ce@sentry.io/178860', {
    release: vi.env.RELEASE,
    environment: vi.env.ENVIRONMENT,
    ignoreErrors: [/SecurityError: Blocked a frame with origin.*/],
  })
  .install();

// Stop using our error handler
window.nyt_errors.ravenInstalled = true;
var regex = /nyt-a=(.*?)(;|$)/;
var id = regex.exec(document.cookie);

if (id !== null) {
  id = id[1];
} else {
  id = '';
}

// Setting nyt-a as user context
window.Raven.setUserContext({
  id: id,
});

// Pass collected errors to Raven
var nytErrorsList = window.nyt_errors.list;
var nytErrorsTags = window.nyt_errors.tags;

for (var i = 0; i < nytErrorsList.length; i += 1) {
  var err = nytErrorsList[i];
  // weird?
  if (!err) { continue; }

  // also weird ... ?
  if (!err.err) {
    // maybe err itself is an Error?
    if (err instanceof Error) {
      window.Raven.captureException(err, err.data || {});
    } // else { silently ignore? }
  }

  // just making sure ...
  if (err.err instanceof Error) {
    window.Raven.captureException(err.err, err.data || {});
  } // else { silently ignore? }
}

// Pass collected Tags to Raven
for (var i = 0; i < nytErrorsTags.length; i += 1) {
  window.Raven.setTagsContext(nytErrorsTags[i]);
}

  }
  window.addEventListener('load', function(event) {
    if (!window.Raven) {
      var includeRaven = document.getElementById("RavenInstaller");
      var script = document.createElement("script");
      script.src = "/vi-assets/static-assets/raven.min-830a6d04a55c283934dd1893d6ddc66d.js";
      script.onload = function() {
        installRaven();
      };
      includeRaven.appendChild(script);
    } else {
      installRaven();
    }
  });
}
</script>
</div>
